definition_data: {"word": "affect", "phonetic": "/əˈfɛkt/", "suggestion": null, "definitions": [{"examples": ["The cold weather will affect the crops.", "Her mood was affected by the news.", "The medication may affect your blood pressure.", "The economic downturn will affect many businesses.", "The teacher's enthusiasm can affect her students' motivation."], "definition": "to influence something or someone, in both emotional and non-emotional contexts.", "cultural_notes": null, "part_of_speech": "verb", "definition_native": "influencer quelque chose ou quelqu'un, tant dans des contextes émotionnels que non émotionnels."}, {"examples": ["She affected a tone of indifference.", "He affected a sense of outrage at the suggestion.", "They affected a nonchalant attitude towards the criticism.", "The actor affected a strong accent for the role.", "The politician was accused of affecting a tone of sincerity."], "definition": "to pretend to have a feeling or emotion; this usage is less common and often implies insincerity.", "cultural_notes": "This sense of 'affect' often implies insincerity.", "part_of_speech": "verb", "definition_native": "prétendre avoir un sentiment ou une émotion ; ce sens est moins courant et implique souvent de l'insincérité."}], "translations": ["avoir un impact sur", "émouvoir", "influencer (note : ce sens se réfère à une personne, pas au verbe)"], "valid_word_score": 1.0}
